markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

buzzfeednews.com  (WEB - en-US)

The homepage for the news operation of Buzzfeed, a developer of innovative viral content in the social media era, such as the “listicle,” as well as a newsroom that produces in-depth journalism.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

BuzzFeed was founded in 2006 by John Johnson and current CEO Jonah Peretti, who also helped launch The Huffington Post with current Buzzfeed Chairman Ken Lerer. In 2011, BuzzFeed announced it was hiring Politico’s Ben Smith to build the news organization that eventually became BuzzFeed News.

Until July 2018, BuzzFeed News content was only published on BuzzFeed.com, alongside the site’s signature viral content, such as shareable quizzes and listicles. BuzzFeed launched BuzzfeedNews.com as a standalone website, although Buzzfeed News stories are published on BuzzFeed.com as well.

BuzzFeed has raised hundreds of millions of dollars from venture capital funds and traditional media, including $400 million in 2015 and 2016 from NBCUniversal. However, the company announced layoffs in late November 2017 after it missed its revenue targets by 15 to 20 percent for the year.

BuzzFeed has been an industry pioneer in creating “native advertising” -- original in-house ads that look like the rest of the site’s content. BuzzFeed also sells cookbooks and cookware at Walmart, sold under the “Tasty” brand, which is also the name of its popular food site.

Content

BuzzFeed News has offices and reporters around the world covering national and international news, politics, crime, arts and culture, health, technology, and business news. The site conducts original reporting and also covers reporting by other news outlets. As of July 2018, BuzzFeed News employs 250 reporters and editors in New York, Los Angeles, Washington, London, Paris, Mexico City, and Tokyo, among many other cities, according to the site.

An investigations team has published deeply reported stories on the drugs used in U.S. executions, corruption in Olympics judging, and abuses at the New York City Police Department.

The site runs a trending news bar at the top of its homepage with phrases such as “Climate Change” or “Confederate Statue” that link to Buzzfeed News stories about those topics. The site also links to Buzzfeed.com at the top of its homepage.

Credibility

BuzzFeed News’ reporters were Pulitzer Prize finalists in both 2017 and 2018 for international reporting. Reporter Chris Hamby’s 18-month investigation on “a dispute-settlement process used by multinational corporations to undermine domestic regulations and gut environmental laws at the expense of poorer nations,” was recognized in 2017. In 2018, the entire staff was cited for reporting that showed operatives with apparent ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin engaged in a campaign to kill Putin’s enemies in the United Kingdom and U.S.

BuzzFeed News’s media editor, Craig Silverman, is a leading authority on the spread of “fake news” and was among the first to use the term while tracking news sites deliberately publishing misinformation. In 2016, he and colleague Lawrence Alexander were among the first reporters to publish a story on U.S. election-related misinformation published by websites hosted in Macedonia.

In early 2017, BuzzFeed News published an unverified dossier of opposition research on Donald Trump that was compiled during the 2016 presidential campaign by former British intelligence officer Christopher Steele. The dossier alleged a conspiracy between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin to damage U.S. Democratic Party interests, naming Trump's personal lawyer as a go-between, and included a salacious allegation about Trump and Russian prostitutes in Moscow.

Much of the information in the dossier, which has influenced public discussions about special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, was unconfirmed. Several other news outlets had obtained it, but declined to publish it. BuzzFeed has faced lawsuits from people mentioned in the dossier.

BuzzFeed acknowledged there were errors in the material, but defended the publication “so that Americans can make up their own minds” about the allegations.

BuzzFeed News runs corrections as necessary. BuzzFeed News clearly labels opinion pieces.

Transparency

In 2015, BuzzFeed published its internal editorial standards and ethics guide online. It bans reporters from engaging in political partisanship in public forums, but said on issues such as  women’s rights, civil rights, and racism, “there are not two sides.”

BuzzFeed News stories have bylines that link to reporter biographies and contact information. An About Us page lists editors, bureau chiefs and directors, but does not provide accompanying contact information.

History

BuzzFeed launched in 2006 as an aggregator of trending and viral content. In August 2016, BuzzFeed announced it was reorganizing into two divisions: BuzzFeed News and BuzzFeed Entertainment. BuzzFeed indicated it was planning to go public in 2018, but major revenue shortfalls in 2017 put those plans on hold.

Written by:
Josh Keefe

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Eric Effron
